questions.question_text:
A technician sets up a new printer on the network, allowing it to obtain an IP address. The technician records the IP address and sets up users to print using the information. The following Monday after powering on the printer, users report they can no longer print. After verifying users can access other network shares, the technician prints a configuration page and sees the IP address has changed.
Which of the following is the BEST method for the technician to ensure this will not happen again?

discussion.content: you could literally static the IP outside of the DHCP range and never have a conflict. I guess the proper way is to do DHCP reserve.

From Mike Meyers book: "Network administrators set up DHCP servers to save IP
addresses for specific functions, such as servers or printers. These are called
DHCP reservations. Typically, any servers have a reserved IP address. A
small network with network ID of 192.168.4.x will commonly reserve .1 for
the default gateway and .2 through .9 for servers."

IP reservation makes the most sense.

V=https://www.stephenwagner.com/2019/05/07/static-ip-vs-dhcp-reservation/#:~:text=A%20static%20IP%20address%20is,server%20for%20an%20IP%20address.
Why is an IP reservation the best option when you could statically assign the printer an IP address?

comments.content: Because an other device can than get the same IP address through dhcp

Not always the case, if a MFC printer is always on(Which usually is the case, or in sleep mode)it will always retain the static IP and dhcp will assign a different IP to the other computer that turns on. Reservation is the correct way to do it though.
Because if u put the Ip address static. The dhcp will distribute the same ip which will cause ip conflict

discussion.content: Nah man MAC filtering is security, whitelist, blacklist etc...IP res would be the better Comptia answer. D would actually work, but again, IP reservation would be the better answer.

Why is C the best.. I would say A is the best.. you just set that MAC address from printer get the same IP every time and that's it... with that method you have to reserver one IP and than go to printer and manualy enter values... takes more time.

choices.B: Set up the users to print using the newly assigned IP address.
choices.A: Set up MAC filtering on the switch to ensure the printer gets the same IP.
choices.C: Create an IP reservation for the printer on the DHCP server.
choices.D: Statically assign the current IP address to the printer.

choices.B: There is a low RFID signal.

discussion.content: It's important to realize the distinction between ISP throttling and internal throttling, a company may be huge and if a technician is on the lower end of the corporate ladder, they may experience throttling from the systems administrator. Good communication, testing with the phone (Outside connection), and calling the ISP are all ways to find out answers to what the source of throttling is. Throttling is very helpful in making sure a system has stability, especially if some users use immense amounts of bandwidth. When it comes to ISP throttling, it can be everything from annoying to downright illegal so keep GREAT documentation when experiences bad service.

comments.content: we can't completely rule out D. phone could be out of range of the tower. he could've still been connected to a more distant cell tower when in fact there is another tower close by - this is due to poor AP handover. in which case, u need to enable/disable airplane mode. so the phone reconnects to the closer tower this time

questions.question_text:
A technician has noticed that when at company headquarters the laptop connection to the Internet is more responsive than when using the company-provided phone as a hotspot. The technician updated the drivers on the WiFi NIC without resolution and then verified the configuration on the WiFi was correct.
Which of the following configurations could cause the decreased performance?

A technician has built a custom workstation for an end user. The end user reports that the workstation ran for a few minutes and then crashed. When the user subsequently boots the workstation, it crashes much more quickly.
Which of the following did the technician forget to do when building the workstation?

comments.content: I disagree! The answer is "CASE fan" and not CPU! Case fans are not neccessary, only one that is needed is CPU fan. So correct answer for me would definitely be thermal paste, because I had issues with dry thermal paste in the past and when I put a new one between I fixed the problem.
Case fans can cause heat build up, but lack/bad thermal paste is much more likely to do that.

Most modern CPUs have integrated heat spreaders (IHS) and some fairly sophisticated thermal management setups. This means that if you start up your PC without a CPU cooler attached then they will start to throttle down to keep temperatures below the maximum allowed package temperature. If they hit the lowest throttling point and they still cannot keep the temperature below the maximum then they will shutdown the PC.

Question doesn't mention CPU fan, only case fans. If there is a CPU fan installed but the case fans aren't plugged in this would allow the CPU to cool itself until the temp inside the case raised to the point it caused a reboot. The temp would then be higher on second boot so it would shut down much more quickly since it is already at (or still close to) reboot temp.
If there was no fan for the CPU, then, the system would NOT start at all.

Case fans are absolutely in a standard workstation. The only time you'd build a system without case fans is if you're building a thin client that has been specifically designed to disperse heat without them. In a normal workstation the CPU fan will cool the heat sync using the air that is inside the case, while the case fans push the hot air out and bring cool air in. Without case fans the air in the system would just get hotter and hotter as the cpu fan spins.
if the lack of fans causes heat buildup then wouldn't the lack of thermal paste cause the cpu to retain heat even more?
some computers run a system check to ensure vans are connected. if it detects the fans are there it will shut off for safety. not even the fact that it got hot, that it doesn't detect them
I think the reason why is most new cpu has thermal paste applied when bought, even though u have CPU fan, but maybe it is still not enough to get the heat off, so you will still need a case fan.

discussion.content: This answer is correct. While the thermal paste is indeed important, it will not be the main cause of the computer shutting down faster the next time it boots. If the tech forgot to connect the fans, they are not pulling the heat out and will shut down faster each time it is booted due to the additional heat building up. So yes, the thermal paste is important but without the fans, the case isn't going to cool off from heat generated by any of the other components that produce heat.

comments.content: I also think answer should be A.

discussion.content: How is this not A?

Selected Answer: B
While the thermal paste is indeed important, it will not be the main cause of the computer shutting down faster the next time it boots. If the tech forgot to connect the fans, they are not pulling the heat out and will shut down faster each time it is booted due to the additional heat building up. So yes, the thermal paste is important but without the fans, the case isn't going to cool off from heat generated by any of the other components that produce heat.

A. Apply thermal paste.
This is the most likely reason for the reported behavior. If the technician forgot to apply thermal paste, the CPU would quickly overheat and cause the system to crash. Initially, the system may have run for a few minutes before overheating, but on subsequent boots, it would crash much more quickly due to residual heat buildup.

B. Connect the case fans.
While not connecting case fans could contribute to heat buildup, it is less likely to cause the system to crash as quickly as described.

Selected Answer: B
270 | The Official CompTIA® A+® Core 1 and Core 2 Student Guide (Exams 220-1001 and 220-1002) - Note: When purchasing a CPU, most CPU fans included already have
thermal paste applied to the bottom of the CPU fan. If there is no thermal paste applied or the CPU didn't come with a CPU fan, then you'll need to purchase a separate tube of thermal paste.
It must be B.
This is a type of question that should have said "Choose Two"

Selected Answer: A
Thermal Paste
I think it's thermal paste, I read somewhere that it's more common for people to forget to add the thermal paste when building computers. Case fans are huge and not easily missed.

The anser is A. thermal paste 

Thermal paste fills these gaps and transfers heat through them so that heat does not get trapped and cause problems.
What happens if you don't use thermal paste on your CPU?

It will turn on and work although, your CPU heat spreader will not be perfectly flat against the CPUcooler block, which is also not perfectly flat. 
This will create air gaps that build up heat between the two. This heat will cause thermal shutdown if you are lucky, 
the death of the CPU if you are not.

comments.content:
For what the case fans are concerned. 

What is important to know is that next to all modern computers wont even start without functional cooling element to the CPU!
And in this case we are talking about a case fan and NOT a CPU fan.

While it is good and you need to have proper ventilation of the machine it is not critical.
But it can cause the same issue, but far from this fast!
What you wil notice is that the computer case wil warm up and starts to radiate some heat.
A clear indication that there is something wrong with the flow of air and the heat is trapped.

Since there is no mention of heat buildup and this is a new custom PC that fails on "first startup".
forgetting to apply thermal paste is more more likely the culprit

discussion.content: I checked another testing site, and it gave the same answer as this one so, that is what I am going with.

comments.content: dude, all the sites pretty much all copy each other with the answers, and there are lots of sites like this one, so whatever

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
because the question says minutes before it shuts down. having no cpu fan will quickly heat up and quicky shuts down it says it takes 20sec. while thermal does take minutes and when you turn on back again the the computer and open a app then it will increase teh temp but not that fast.

The key detail is that the PC crashes after a few minutes. Lack of thermal paste will cause the PC to crash eventually if under heavier operational conditions. But a completely inactive CPU fan is more likely to cause a crash to occur within a few minutes of boot.

Option A/B are good and based on the definition I have the thermal paste will help to make a complete contacted between CPU and Heatsink. in easy words it fills up the gap air between these two components. This is a good but it still the natural airflow that goes through a PC case it won't be as strong as having a FAN connected to CPU or a FAN attached to the case that pushes fresh air into the motherboard. Providing a better airflow to cool the components in this case CPU!
based on this analogy i will go with option B.
imma rock out with A on this one boys. I cant recall where but somewhere when I was taking a practice test it said something about Thermal Paste being easy to forget. and I think that applies here.
Lets look at the problem in a different way ….Let us assume there is a CPU fan in place and working but the technician forgot to put thermal paste. Will the CPU overheat and stop ?

comments.content: Yes, It happened to me. Didn't forgot to apply thermal paste, but the paste applied was not appropriate to the amount of heat generated by the CPU. There were heat build up and the PC were shutting down several times.

discussion.content: Probably it is B. But in real life a newly built workstation would have been checked before being given to the end user. Bad technician.

choices.D: Plug the laptop into a UPS.
choices.A: Plug the laptop into another power outlet.

questions.question_text:
An end user brings in a laptop that no longer charges. A technician troubleshoots the laptop and notices it works while the power adaptor is plugged in but shuts down as soon as it is unplugged.
Which of the following is the NEXT best step to resolve this issue?

discussion.content:
From Mike Meyers book: "If the printer reports a jam
but there’s no paper inside, you almost certainly have a problem with one of
the many jam sensors or paper feed sensors inside the printer, and you’ll need
to take it to a repair center."

A is the correct answer
A paper path is the route that paper takes through a printer from the input tray to the output tray. A blocked sensor is a sensor that detects paper jams or other errors in the paper path but fails to clear after the problem is resolved. A blocked sensor can cause a printer to display an error message even after a paper jam is cleared.
The technician should check the paper path for any debris or obstructions that may trigger the sensor.

choices.A: Check the paper path for blocked sensors.
choices.D: Verify the pickup rollers are in working order.

questions.question_text:
A user states the department laser printer continues to display a paper jam error message despite the jam being cleared.
Which of the following should a technician do to troubleshoot this problem?
